Award.AbstractNarration:
The most challenging problem in theoretical physics is the unification of the laws of quantum physics with Einstein's general theory of relativity. The ideas in this direction that have been pursued most forcefully are superstring theory and noncommutative geometry. These two approaches are intimately related. Noncommutative geometry has provided a new framework to study spaces which could not be handled by the standard methods of Riemannian geometry. It provides a new perspective in the study of gauge theories and is a promising candidate to describe geometries at Planckian energies. The main focus of this proposal is to study the nature of space-time at subplanckian scales, determining the dynamics and finding connections between superstring theory and noncommutative geometry. It is essential to find the noncommutative space-time whose limit is the product of a continuous four-dimensional manifold times a finite space that reproduces the standard model. Also to be invesigated will be the functional integral for chiral Dirac operators in the random matrix approximation, deforming space-time with continuous parameters, heat kernel methods to find boundary terms for the spectral action, adding an inflaton, dilaton and axion, the behavior of spectral actions in presence of singularities and nonperturbative evolution of the dynamical fields at scales of the order of the planck length. Topological five-dimensional gravity, regular BPS solutions with cylindrical symmetry, and exact solutions for the bigravity system will be studied.
Broader impact : Due to its interdisciplinary nature, this work, on the frontiers of noncommutative geometry and string theory, will be of benefit to both physicists and mathematicians. The American University of Beirut (AUB) plays a very important role in promoting the American educational system in the Middle East. Historically, the emphasis was on liberal education. The new aim is to provide in addition a vibrant environment for the promotion of research. The launching of the Ph.D. program in theoretical physics in October 2008 is a step in this direction and will hopefully attract students of high caliber from other universities in the Middle East.

In Euclidean geometry parallel lines do not meet as dictated by the fifth postulate. In the middle of the 19th century non Euclidean geometry where the fifth postulate  does not hold was shown to exist, which culminated in the work of Riemann in his construction of Riemannian geometry. Einstein showed that the presence of matter curves the four-dimensional space-time according to the rules of  Riemannian geometry. In particular, the universal law of gravitation is obtained from a variational principle of an action expressed in terms of the curvature of space-time. Thus the dynamics of the gravitational force is geometric in nature. There are three other fundamental forces: The electromagnetic force, the weak nuclear force and the strong nuclear force. These three forces govern the interactions of the elementary particles which constitute the building blocks of all matter found in nature. The elementary particles are given by three families of 16 chiral (massless) fermions known as the quarks and leptons. The first family consists of massive electron, neutrino, up quark and down quark (the quarks come with three colors). The three forces are mediated by gauge vector bosons, the photon, three W± and Z bosons and eight gluons. In addition there is a scalar boson, the Higgs particle, responsible for giving masses to all fermions and gauge bosons. The dynamics of all these particles and interactions are described to an amazingly high degree of precision by the Standard Model of particle physics. Unlike the gravitational force, the three gauge forces do not follow from the geometry of space-time. A fundamental question facing theoretical physics is whether all four forces could be unified within a grand setting, which will pave the way to finding a consistent theory of quantum gravity. 

The work of von Neumann in the beginning of the 20th Century on the classification of operator algebras revealed the existence of a new geometry, which he named type III. This geometry was constructed in the ground breaking work of Alain Connes in 1978 for which he was awarded the Fields medal in mathematics. This is a new kind of geometry where coordinates are replaced with operators, and the metric with which distances are measured is replaced with a differential operator whose spectrum could be evaluated. The study of geometry becomes spectral in nature, and is very well suited to blend with quantum mechanics. A well posed question in mathematics is whether it is possible to hear the shape of the drum? In other words to reconstruct the geometry of the drum from the knowledge of the fundamental tones. Although this question was answered in the negative within Reimannian geometry, where mathematicians found counterexamples of manifolds having the same spectra, it has been recently shown by Alain Connes that the question has a positive answer when formulated in terms of the spectral data of noncommutative geometry. A similar question can then be asked of whether the observed spectrum of particles and their interactions could be used to determine the geometry of space-time. The aim of this project is to examine the hypothesis that all fundamental forces in nature as well as the particle spectrum result as a consequence of a geometric principle and define a noncommutative space-time. This is a grand unification generalization of Einstein's formulation of gravity as a geometric theory. In a long-term collaborative research with the mathematician Alain Connes we have identified the noncommutative space that produces the Standard Model unified with gravity.
